utterances: E.J., you wanted to jump in there.

Yeah, I think the difficulty with what David is saying is that it implies that you can defeat ISIS with political instability continuing in Baghdad, with the lack of support from the Sunnis for the central government in Baghdad.
And I think yes, Obama has a tendency to be agonized over a lot of choices.
But guess what?
There are a lot of agonizing choices.
And I think yes, we do want to defeat ISIS.
We don't want them to gain more ground, and we sure don't want them to overrun the Kurds.
So I think the logic of this campaign is we will probably get more involved than the administration is now.
But I think Obama's right that absent some political change in Baghdad, we just can't do this - or even we and allies can't do this without political change.
You know, a lot of people are asking if you can do this in Iraq, why not do it in Syria?
What's the difference in terms of a humanitarian crisis and thousands of people being jeopardized?
Is there one?
170,000 people have died in Syria, and much worse atrocities.
I think the lesson of Syria - and maybe the lesson here is the same - which is it's a lot easier to do the small things at the beginning than to do big things at the end.
And we - now we're beginning to arm the moderate rebels in Syria, but we probably should have been there more assertively in the beginning when they actually had a chance.
And we should've probably defeated ISIS or tried to fight against them in the beginning now - not now that they control so much territory.
But the larger point is that if you're constantly assertive with coalitions, it's a lot easier than if your tendency is one to retrench and withdrawal.
I think the answer to your question is that A, we have more responsibility in Iraq simply because we were there before and are partly responsible for political circumstances there.
Second, we are dealing with clear allies there in the Iraqi government, but even more in the Kurds.
And I think the very fact that the opposition in Syria gave rise to ISIS suggests how complicated it was.
A lot of people - David is one of them - says if we'd only come in earlier and armed moderates, then maybe none of this would have happened.
They wouldn't have risen.
The other possibility is those weapons could eventually have gotten into ISIS hands.
So I think Syria was not as clear as this is, at least to me.
And we did hear President Obama last night specifically mention having a mandate to help - in this case, a request from the Iraqi government.
Correct.
The White House idea - and E.J., you alluded to this earlier - was that the Iraqis would have to come together on a new government and political reforms for there to be any real further U.S.
military involvement.
Is there any promise of that?
Is that completely by the wayside this point, David?
I don't think so.
I actually think the Obama administration has done a pretty good job of trying to rally some sort of unified - trying to get Maliki out of there - trying to rally some sort of unified government.
That's just a question of twisting arms and trying to get help from outside to rally a coalition of people to create a new set of political leadership.

That - you know, it looks more promising, frankly, than it did a month or two ago - that that would happen - that we'd have a different government in there - one a broader swath would support that would be less sectarian.

The problem is this will - you know, even if they form a government, it's just going to take a long time to get the government organized, let alone to get the military - the Iraqi military organized, and ISIS can do a lot of damage in that time.
E.J.
There's nothing like an existential threat to concentrate people's minds.
And I think there is a lot of awareness among political leaders in Iraq that they - if they do not act reasonably quickly, this situation is going to get worse.
So yes, it's very hard.
Yes, there are no really inspiring leaders on the list to replace Maliki.

Nonetheless, they're looking at either the collapse of the regime or a loss of half their country, and that should put some pressure on the Iraqi politicians to get moving on forming a new government.
OK, thanks so much to both have a great weekend.
Thank you.
Thank you.
E.J.
Dionne of the Washington Post and Brookings Institution, and David Brooks of the New York Times.
Israel says it invaded the Gaza Strip in part to destroy tunnels used by militants.
Today, a Hamas video claims to show an attack launched on Israeli troops from a tunnel.
Israelis are asking why their forces didn't stop Hamas from building the underground network in the first place, and some want an investigation.
NPR 's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson has that story.
In the grainy Hamas video, black-clad militants shove their weapons through a tunnel entrance, then climb out and run toward what looks like an army post inside Israel.
Five soldiers were killed in yesterday's attack, as were a handful of Hamas fighters.
Israeli officials say the militants' aim was to kill and kidnap Israeli citizens.

Such revelations are rattling Israelis more than the 2000 plus rockets Hamas has fired into their country since the war began earlier this month says Smadar Perry, who writes about the tunnels for Israel's largest daily newspaper, Yedioth Ahronoth.
Nobody wants to go to sleep and wake up with killers and terrorists in his bedroom.

But she and other journalists say how Hamas was able to build enough tunnels to allow militants to infiltrate Israel six times since the Gaza offensive began is something Israeli authorities will likely have to answer for.
At a briefing earlier this week, Israeli Intelligence Minister Yuval Steinitz defended how authorities have dealt with the tunnels of which the military says 32 have been uncovered so far.
You know it's not always the case that if we have some threats we decide immediately to go to a big ground operation in order to neutralize it.
Perry, however, says she found few officials who were concerned about the tunnels before some of the newer, more sophisticated versions were accidentally uncovered earlier this year.
The journalist toured one of them with a senior Israeli officer.
But first to Miami.
Late last night, a spokesman in Havana announced that Cuban President Fidel Castro is ill and had transferred power to his brother, Raul Castro.
After that stunning news, most people in Havana went about their business.
But in Miami, many Cubans went wild.
Over nearly five decades, hundreds of thousands fled Castro's rule.
Many of them settled in South Florida.
The streets of Miami's Little Havana overflowed with celebrations last night and again today.
Joining us now is Myriam Marquez.
She's immigration editor and assistant city editor of the Miami Herald.
She joins us now by phone from her office there.
Nice to have you back on TALK OF THE NATION.
Hi, Neal.
Thank you.
We've seen pictures of people dancing in the streets.
What's it like there today?
Well, the mood is a little more tentative.
People are trying to make out what exactly it is that's occurring.
You know, there's this strong feeling, and it's a feeling within the exile community of wishful thinking that, oh, he's probably already dead.
And therefore, as happens in totalitarian regimes, they take - you know, they sort of use the message sparingly until they get to the right moment when they will release it.
But I think today it's a little, you know, more cautious.
There's the question of exactly, you know, what does this mean for certainly the hard-line elements of the exile community?
Raul Castro is not an acceptable option as the next in line.
So it's interesting.
Right now there's this - talk radio is going nuts with…
Hmm.
…a lot of, you know, people talking about let's go and let's deal with it over there.
But that always happens.
You mentioned some people believing he's already dead.
The news that we're getting is that he is resting peacefully after surgery last night.
Exactly.
But I assume rumors are rife.
Rumors are rife.
Exactly.
And people are - and I think it's, obviously it's generational for a lot of the older folks.
I mean, they see this as the opportunity, and they're thinking that his health was such that it was - he was prime to become very ill.
Last week when he was in Argentina, Fidel Castro had a - just a stressful time.
And I saw some of the reports from there in Spanish television, and definitely, he seemed stressed out.
A lot of pressure from Argentinean president about some immigration issues.
And I think that that was the - that was coming to bare.
And you mentioned a generational split.
Looking at the pictures, it seemed like everybody was united.
Oh, absolutely.
Absolutely, people are out there.

I mean, I think the, you know, second and third generation Cuban-Americans - you know, with their grandparents, or their parents who were born in Cuba - they grow up being taught about what the struggles were.
So in that sense, yes.
But I think the difference is, you know, the tactic of what to do from now on.
There - I think the younger folks are much more inclined to wait and see - see where the Cuban people are going to take this.
The older folks are more inclined to say what can we do to make this happen now?
They're the ones that, you know, are pulling the strings when it comes to the Cuba transition report from the Bush administration.
They're the one's that, you know, get out the vote for the Republican Party.
And they're certainly the one's that, you know, that the leadership of this country looks at for advice when it comes to Cuba.
There are some who believe that if Fidel Castro does die, and a lot of Cubans are going to advantage of the opportunity and try to migrate themselves.
Yes.

And obviously, there is a plan in place in federal, state, and locally as to what - how to deal - you know, Miami-Dade County has a long, long history of how to deal with the issues of folks washing up to our shores.
So there is a plan in place.
And the city and Miami-Dade has already started that plan to just monitor the streets and be more careful, because what we don't want is an exodus from here going out to try to pickup relatives.
That's happened with Mariel, or just having folks come on over.
And the Coast Guard, of course, is, you know, cautiously watching this situation.
Is there a belief that some people in the coming days or weeks or months ahead will be able to get back to Cuba to reclaim houses and the businesses that they left so long ago?
That's always - that's always been part - that's always been simmering at the bottom of this issue of 47 years, you know.
There is talk about that.
Interestingly, that there just happens to be - Miami-Dade College has a three-day symposium starting in a couple of days on Cuba.
And one of the issues that was - is going to be discussed is the issue of reclamation.
How do you get either money back for your property, or some kind of, you know, fairness issue?
And I think they're looking at what's happened in Eastern Europe, certainly in East Germany as a model.
Hmm.
A lot of people in Cuba worry about that, too.
They've been living in some of those houses for a very long time.
Absolutely.
Absolutely.

And that's where the point is that, you know, you can start to hear some of the commentators here saying, well, we're -no one - radio commentators I'm talking about - no one's going to go in and take people's property.
But there should be some kind of mechanism to ensure that those who are forced to leave, who were kicked out of their own country, have some way to, you know, get some kind of compensation for it.
So that's the big bugaboo in all of this, obviously.
That's what's the big question mark.
Myriam Marquez.
Thanks very much for your time.
We appreciate it.
Thank you.
Myriam Marquez, immigration editor for the Miami Herald.
She joined us by phone from her office in Miami.
Last Thursday, we talked in depth about Cuba after Castro.
If you missed that conversation, you can hear it online at npr.org.
Thanks much for being with us.
You're welcome.
I want to ask you about an exchange this week between Senator John Warner of Virginia and General Petraeus.
If we continue what you have laid before the Congress here as a strategy, do you feel that that is making America safer?
Sir, I believe that this is indeed the best course of action to achieve our objectives in Iraq.
